title: 108_s2602
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" and it involves the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and each of the territories. The Act titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" involves redesigning quarter dollars in 2009 to honor the District of Columbia and the territories, with designs emblematic of each. The Secretary has flexibility in selecting designs for the coins. The redesign of quarter dollars in 2009 under the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" includes inscriptions on the reverse and obverse sides of the coins, with designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and various territories. The Secretary has the authority to select the specific designs for the coins. The redesign of quarter dollars in 2009 under the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" involves selecting 6 designs for the coins, with input from the chief executive of the District of Columbia or the honored territory, the Commission of Fine Arts, and review by the Citizens Coinage. The redesign of quarter dollars in 2009 involves selecting 6 designs for the coins, with input from officials, artists, engravers, and the general public, to ensure dignified designs for the Nation's coinage and currency. The Secretary must ensure that no frivolous or inappropriate designs are selected for quarter dollars minted under this subsection. Portraits of any person, living or dead, are prohibited in the design. All coins minted under this subsection are considered numismatic items. The Secretary may mint and issue a certain number of quarter dollars of each design in uncirculated and proof quality. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars in uncirculated and proof qualities with 90% silver and 10% copper. Coins honoring the District of Columbia and territories will be issued in equal intervals during 2009. The legislation applies to Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. If the District of Columbia or any territory becomes a state within 10 years, specific provisions will apply. If a territory becomes independent before quarter dollars are minted to represent it, different rules will apply. The legislation applies to Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The term 'territory' includes these areas.
